questions.text: A 34 year old construction worker with no comorbidities presents with exertional pain in both forearms and hands. He smokes 1 pack of cigarettes per day. On examination, brachial pulses are palpable but radial and ulnar pulses are feeble. Image  of his hand is shown. Angiography of his upper extremity shows smooth tapering segmental lesions in the distal arterial vessels. Which of the following treatments has the greatest chances of success?
questions.solution:
This is a classical clinical scenario of thromboangiitis obliterans. There is no specific treatment except abstinence from tobacco.

Key points in the question:

  • Male < 40years
  • Smoker
  • Involvement of upper extremity
  • Raynauds phenomenon

Thromboangiitis Obliterans (Buerger’s disease):

  • An inflammatory occlusive vascular disorder involving small and medium-sized arteries and veins in the distal upper and lower extremities.
  • Most common in men <40 years of age.
  • Although the cause of thromboangiitis obliterans is not known, there is a definite relationship to cigarette smoking in patients with this disorder.
  • MRA, CTA, and conventional arteriography show smooth, tapering segmental lesions in the distal vessels with collateral vessels at sites of vascular occlusion.
  • There is no specific treatment except abstention from tobacco.
  • The prognosis is worse in individuals who continue to smoke, but results are discouraging even in those who stop smoking.
  • Antibiotics may be useful.
  • Anticoagulants and glucocorticoids are not helpful.
  • If these measures fail, amputation may be required.

No Smoking Day is observed every year on the second Wednesday of March. The aim of the campaign is to encourage people over the world to quit smoking. The main purpose of this day is to spread awareness about the harmful health effects of tobacco consumption through cigarette and other modes.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents with irregular periods, acne & excessive hair growth. What is the first line management?
questions.solution:
The first line of treatment for this woman with signs and symptoms of polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) such as irregular periods, acne & excessive hair growth (hirsutism) is lifestyle modification.

PCOS is an endocrinopathy seen in women of reproductive age, affecting multiple systems. A weight loss of 10% through lifestyle modifications such as diet and exercise are considered first-line.

The Rotterdam criteria are used to diagnose PCOS. The presence of any two of the three components of this criteria establishes the diagnosis of PCOS:

  • Clinical/biochemical hyperandrogenism (hirsutism, acne)
  • Menstrual abnormalities (oligomenorrhea/amenorrhea), anovulation, infertility
  • Polycystic ovaries on ultrasonography.

Sonographic criteria for polycystic ovaries include ≥ 12 small cysts or an increased ovarian volume (> 10 mL) or both. 

Management:

  • Weight reduction and lifestyle changes are considered the first-line treatment for infertility in obese women with PCOS.
  • Clomiphene citrate is the first-line pharmacological choice for ovulation induction in PCOS (Option B).
  • Gonadotropins are second-line.(Aromatase inhibitors like letrozole are now not used to treat infertility in these patients)
  • Patients with PCOD are more prone to developing insulin resistance which can be controlled with metformin (Option C). 
  • Oral contraceptive pills (OCP), preferably fourth-generation are used to treat menstrual abnormalities. It also reduces acne and further hirsutism (Option D).
  • Anti-androgens are useful in treating hirsutism. OCP with cyproterone acetate is prescribed for PCOS patients with hirsutism. 

Surgical options include laparoscopic ovarian drilling or puncture of not more than four cysts in each ovary. It restores endocrine levels and improves fertility. Surgery is indicated only in the case of

  • Failure of medical therapy
  • Hyperstimulation
  • Infertile women
  • Previous pregnancy losses

questions.text: After a surgery, the surgeon asked the intern to remove the Foley's catheter but he/she could not do it. The surgeon himself tried to remove it but he was unsuccessful as well. What should be the next step of action?

choices.text: CT-guided rupture of bulb of Foley's
Inject ether to dissolve the balloon and pull it out
Inject water to overdistend the balloon until it bursts and Foley's can be removed
Use ultrasound guidance to locate and prick the balloon after inflating with 20ml water

questions.solution:
The best technique in this situation is ultrasound-guided rupture of the balloon percutaneously after inflating it with 20ml water. It is important subsequently to cystoscope the patient to ensure that any fragments are removed before they can form a foreign body calculus.

A retained Foley catheter is usually caused by blockage of the channel that connects the balloon to the side arm. Cutting off the side arm and attempting to clear the channel with a wire is only occasionally successful.

questions.text: Demographic gap starts contracting in the _________ phase.
questions.solution:
Demographic gap starts contracting in the late expanding phase (STAGE 3).

Related Pearl: Demographic Process and Cycle

  • Demographic process
    • Fertility
    • Mortality
    • Marriage
    • Migration
    • Social Mobility
  • Demographic cycle
    • Stage 1 : High stationary 
      • High birth rate and high death rate render the population stationary.
      • Narrow demographic gap.
    • Stage 2 : Early expanding 
      • Death rate declines and birth rate remains unchanged
      • Demographic gap starts increasing and then becomes maximum
    • Stage 3 : Late expanding
      • Death rate decline further and birth rate falls
      • India is in this stage, currently
      • Demographic gap starts declining
    • Stage 4 : Low stationary 
      • Low birth rate and low death rate renders the population stationary
      • Narrow demographic gap
    • Stage 5 : Declining 
      • Population begins to decline as birth rate is lower than death rate
      • Demographic gap is negative

questions.text: Iron absorption takes place in the _____.

choices.text: Proximal small intestine under basic condition
Proximal small intestine under acidic condition
Distal small intestine under basic condition
Distal small intestine under acidic condition

questions.solution:
Iron absorption takes place in the proximal small intestine under acidic conditions.

  • Dietary iron present as heme is efficiently absorbed; but non-heme iron is less efficiently absorbed mainly because of interference by phosphates, tannins, oxalates and other food constituents.
  • Iron is absorbed into the luminal cell in the ferrous form by DMT-1 also known as natural resistance-associated macrophage protein type 2 (Nramp2)
  • The acidic contents of the stomach facilitate the conversion of ferric (Fe3+) iron to ferrous (Fe2+) iron by an enzyme called ferrireductase.
  • Once inside the cell, the iron can be stored as ferritin, or be released at the basolateral surface through ferroportin. 
  • Hephaestin is a ferroxidase that converts ferrous (Fe2+) iron into ferric (Fe3+) form for binding to transferrin in the plasma.

questions.text: Which of the following is used to estimate the visual field?
questions.solution:
• All the options are used to estimate the visual field.
  • Types:
    • Manual perimetry: Confrontation method, Lister’s perimeter, Campimetry (Scotometry), Goldmann’s perimeter
    • Automated perimetry: Octopus Fieldmaster, Humphrey Field Analyzer

The image given below shows Lister's perimeter.

Image: The above image shows the confrontation method for testing the visual field.

questions.text: Suitable cases for expectant management in case of placenta previa include all except:
questions.solution:
The duration of pregnancy must be less than 37 weeks for expectant management which was advocated by McAfee and Johnson. 

The aim of conservative management is to continue the pregnancy for fetal maturity without compromising maternal health.

Prerequisites:

  • Availability of blood for transfusion 
  • Facilities for cesarean section available 

Selection of cases for expectant management for placenta previa: 

  1. Mother is hemodynamically stable (Hb >10 g% and/or hematocrit > 30%) 
  2. Duration of pregnancy <37 weeks 
  3. No active vaginal bleeding 
  4. Fetus normal on USG and reactive on CTG

Conduct of expectant treatment: 

  • Corticosteroids for fetal lung maturity 
  • Bed rest or pelvic rest
  • Periodic monitoring of mother for bleeding pv
  • Fetal surveillance with USG  
  • Tocolytics if contractions are present
  • Anti-D to all Rh-negative (unsensitized) women.

questions.text: A man presents to the ER with a gunshot wound to the abdomen as shown below. On examination, the peritoneum is breached. BP is 114/78 mmHg and HR is 80 bpm. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate management for a patient with a gunshot wound to the anterior abdominal wall with a breach of the peritoneum is laparotomy.

The incidence of significant injury to the intraperitoneal organs increases manifold when there is a breach of the peritoneum due to any penetrating trauma injury. The indications for doing laparotomy in patients with penetrating abdominal wounds include:

  • Hemodynamic instability
  • Gunshot wound which breaches the peritoneum
  • Evisceration
  • Bleeding from the stomach, rectum, or genitourinary tract following penetrating trauma
  • Peritonitis
  • Free air in the peritoneal cavity
  • Diagnostic peritoneal lavage has bile, gastrointestinal contents or ≥10 cc of blood

CT scan of the abdomen (option B) should be performed in patients with blunt or penetrating abdominal trauma, provided they are hemodynamically stable and have no indication for immediate laparotomy. The patient in question has a gunshot wound to the anterior abdominal wall with a peritoneal breach, which is an indication for exploratory laparotomy as it carries a high risk of organ injury. FAST (option C) is primarily indicated in patients with blunt abdominal trauma with or without hemodynamic instability. It is not a sensitive investigation to detect hollow visceral injury in patients with penetrating abdominal trauma. There is no role for observation (option D) in this patient.

questions.text: A patient with acute pancreatitis was admitted following an episode of binge drinking. 7-days post-admission, he complains of fever with chills and rigor. Blood investigation shows a WBC count of 21,450. CT scan reveals the presence of extraluminal gas in the pancreatic tissue. How will you manage this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a history of pancreatitis, elevated WBC, and CT scan findings are suggestive of pancreatic abscess. It is treated by percutaneous drainage.

A pancreatic abscess is a circumscribed intra-abdominal collection of pus, usually in proximity to the pancreas. It may be an acute fluid collection or walled-off necrosis that has become infected.

Clinical features include:

  • Fever with chills
  • Elevated white blood cell count
  • Abdominal pain

Contrast-enhanced CT and MRI are both options for the assessment of pancreatic necrosis and abscesses. On imaging, the presence of extraluminal gas in the pancreatic and/or peripancreatic tissues is consistent with an underlying infection.

Treatment is by percutaneous drainage with the widest possible drains placed under imaging guidance, along with appropriate antibiotics and supportive care.

questions.text: A woman diagnosed with DCIS underwent surgery and is now posted for adjuvant radiotherapy with external beam radiotherapy. Which of the following isotopes is commonly used for the same?
questions.solution:
Cobalt-60 isotope is used for external beam radiotherapy (EBRT).

External beam radiotherapy is given as follows:

  • Cobalt machine - Co-60 produces gamma rays. It emits radiation of energy 1.25 MeV.
  • LINAC (linear accelator) - X-ray beams are generated to provide ionising radiation.

The energy spectrum used in radiotehrapy is classified as follows:

  • Orthovoltage - 200-500kV x-rays are produced. It is used to treat skin conditions. 
  • Megavoltage - 1-25 MV x-rays are produced. These are used in modern radiotherapy.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true regarding piebaldism?

choices.text: Small spots of hyperpigmentation can also be seen

questions.solution:
White forelock is quite common in Piebaldism.

Piebaldism:

  • Autosomal dominant benign condition, it has mutations in c‐KIT.
  • Well-defined irregular hypopigmented macules with an absence of melnocytes.
  • Small spots of hyperpigmentation are also seen within hypopigmented patches or on normal skin. 
  • It is often associated with a V-shaped leucoderma on mid-forehead.
  • Both sexes are equally affected.
  • Piebaldism can be distinguished from vitiligo because of the neonatal presence of white patches.
  • Epidermal cell or skin grafting is the treatment.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with hepatitis B infection. Which of the following markers will always be present in his serum, even during recurrences, or if he develops chronic hepatitis?
questions.solution:
A patient who has had exposure to HBV will have Anti HBc antibodies even when he has moved into the chronic or recurrent stages. IgM anti-HBc reappears during acute recurrences while IgG Anti HBc is found in chronic states. 

Related Pearl: Interpretation of common serologic patterns in hepatitis B infection

 

 Clinical Phases HBsAg Anti-HBs HBeAg Anti-HBe Anti-HBc HBV DNA
Acute HBV - Early-phase, high infectivity

+

 - + - IgM +++

Acute HBV -Window phase

-

 - - - IgM +

Acute HBV - recovery phase

-

 + - + IgG +/-
Chronic HBV, high infectivity + - + - IgG +++

Chronic HBV, low infectivity

 + - - + IgG +

HBV infection in the recent past

 - + - - IgG -

HBV infection in the remote past

 - - - +/- IgG -

Post-vaccination

 - + - - - -

questions.text: A 71-year-old man presents to the OPD with high-grade fever, productive cough. On examination, the respiratory rate was found to be 32/ min, heart rate of 102/ min, and blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg. How will you manage this patient?

choices.text: Admit to ICU and treat with azithromycin and ceftriaxone
Admit to the ward and treat with levofloxacin and doxycycline
Treat him on OP basis with azithromycin and ceftriaxone
Admit to the ward and treat with azithromycin and levofloxacin

questions.solution: The given clinical scenario is highly suggestive of lobar pneumonia and the patient belongs to a CURB-65 score of 3. The patient can be best managed by a combination of azithromycin and ceftriaxone in an ICU setting. After culture sensitivity, specific management is done.

questions.text: Which of the following vaccine vials can be used based on the vaccine vial monitor (VVM) color changes shown?
questions.solution:
• From the above image, only vials 1 and 2 can be used as the inner squares of the VVMs are lighter than the outer circles.
  • Vial 3 has crossed the discard point as the inner square and outer circle are the same color (if not, the inner square is a little darker than the outer circle) and thus cannot be used.
  • Vial 4 cannot be used as the VVM shows a darker inner square.

Related Pearl: Vaccine Vial Monitors

  • Vaccine vial monitors are used to monitor heat exposure of vaccines.
  • It is a chemical indicator that records the cumulative heat exposure through a gradual change in color.
  • If the color of the inner square is the same color or darker than the outer circle, it indicates that the vaccine has been exposed to too much heat and it must be discarded.
  • Currently, there are four types of VVMs (VVM2, VVM7, VVM14, and VVM30). They are chosen to match the heat sensitivity of the vaccine.
  • The VVM can be located on the label of the vaccine or on the neck or cap of the ampule/vial.
  • VVMs also help in reduction of vaccine wastage by indicating which batch of vaccines can be used first.

questions.text: The knee deformity shown below is called as _____
questions.solution:
The deformity shown is genu valgum.

A normal knee has 5-7 degrees physiological outward deviation. Any increase or decrease in angle can result in knee deformities. 

Knee deformities are:

  • Genu valgus (valgum) or knock knee - Knees are abnormally approximated and the ankles are divergent.
  • Genu varus (varum) or bow knee - Knees are abnormally divergent  and the ankles are approximated.
  • Windswept deformity - Abnormal valgus deformity of one knee with varus of the other.
  • Genu recurvatum - Hyperextension at knee joint, knee bends backwards.

questions.text: ECG of a patient who presented with palpitations to the ER is shown below. Which of the following is a likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above ECG shows increased heart rate with wide QRS complexes (> 0.12s). This is suggestive of ventricular tachycardia (VT). 

Types of ventricular tachycardia based on QRS morphology:

  • Monomorphic- a stable QRS morphology from beat to beat
  • Polymorphic- changing or multiform QRS variance from beat to beat. Torsades de pointes is an example of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia.
  • Bidirectional- has a beat-to-beat alternation in the QRS frontal plane axis. It is associated with digitalis toxicity or catecholaminergic polymorphic VT.

The most common cause of VT is ischemic heart disease.

Ventricular tachyarrhythmias occur due to impulses that originate within the ventricles. These impulses are conducted through the normal ventricular myocardial cells instead of the fast conducting Purkinje system. Hence, they present with wide QRS complexes ( >0.12 sec) on the ECG.

Supraventricular tachyarrhythmias occur due to impulses originating above the ventricles. These impulses reach the ventricles through the proper fast conduction pathway resulting in a narrow QRS complex. SVTs are associated with wide QRS in few exceptional conditions like:

  • Conduction block in the left or right bundle branch
  • Activation of ventricles from an accessory pathway- antidromic AVRT

The given ECG shows wide stable QRS complexes in monomorphic ventricular tachycardia:

Related Pearl: Supraventricular tachycardias

 

Supraventricular tachycardias with narrow QRS complex:

  • Narrow QRS with regular RR interval
   Tachycardia                ECG features
Sinus tachycardia Normal P wave, normal ECG features except for the rate
Focal atrial tachycardia A single type of abnormal p wave morphology is seen
Junctional tachycardia No p waves. Heart rate is 100- 200/ min
AV nodal reentry tachycardia No p waves. Pseudo R' waves may be seen. Heart rate is 150-250/ min
Atrioventricular reentry tachycardia P wave always follows QRS. RP interval< PR interval
Atrial flutter Sawtooth shaped flutter waves are seen

 

  • Narrow QRS with irregular RR interval
     Tachycardia        ECG features
Atrial fibrillation No distinct p waves seen
Multifocal atrial tachycardia More than 3 different abnormal p wave morphologies are seen
Atrial flutter/tachycardia with variable block ECG features of heart block are seen.

 

Supraventricular tachycardias with wide QRS complex:

  • Antidromic AVRT (atrioventricular reentry tachycardia)
  • Supraventricular tachycardias with bundle branch block

Related Pearl: Anti-arrhythmic drugs

Class of antiarrhythmic drugs 

 

Mechanism of action

Effect on action potential duration

Class I

    

Class IA

Procainamide

Quinidine

Disopyramide

 

Na+ channel blockers with significant K+ channel blocking property

 

Prolonged

Lidocaine

Mexiletine

 Na+ channel blockers with K+ channel opening property 

Shortened or no effect

Flecainide

Propafenone

Variable or no effect

questions.text: All of the following are used to assess difficult airway except_____
questions.solution:
ASA classification is used to quantify patient risk for anesthesia and not difficult airway

Related Pearl: Predictors of Difficult Airway

Risk factors:

  • Obstructive sleep apnea
  • History of snoring
  • Obesity
  • Facial and neck deformities from previous surgery
  • Previous head and neck radiation
  • Head and neck trauma
  • Congenital abnormalities of the head and neck
  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Down syndrome
  • Scleroderma
  • Cervical spine disease or previous cervical spine surgery

Specific tests for assessment:

  • Mallampati scores (III and IV)
  • Thyromental distance <6.5 cm with head in maximum extension
  • Sterno-mental distance <12.5 cm with head in maximum extension
  • Increased neck circumference (>17 inches in men or >16 inches in women)
  • Upper lip bite test : Inability to protrude the mandible or lower teeth in front of the upper teeth
  • Cormack and Lehane (laryngoscopic view) - Grade III and IV

Although the presence of these risk factors may not be sensitive in detecting a difficult intubation, the absence of these findings indicates an ease with intubation.

Related Pearl: Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification

Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification is used to predict the ease of endotracheal intubation.

  • Class I: soft palate, fauces, entire uvula, pillars;
  • Class II: soft palate, fauces, the portion of uvula;
  • Class III: soft palate, the base of uvula;
  • Class IV: hard palate only.

questions.text: The spinal cord develops from the______.
questions.solution:
The spinal cord develops from the caudal part of the neural tube.

The nervous system develops from the neurectoderm, the specialized ectoderm overlying the notochord. The neuroectoderm initially thickens to form the neural plate. The neural plate is then converted to a neural groove, followed by a neural tube.

  • The enlarged cranial part of neural tube forms the brain. It has 3 primary vesicles that form forebrain (prosencephalon), midbrain (mesencephalon), and hindbrain (rhombencephalon). 
  • The narrow caudal part of the neural tube forms the spinal cord.

questions.text: Dutcher bodies are seen in_____.
questions.solution:
Dutcher bodies are pale-staining intranuclear inclusions within plasma cells containing Ig, which are more common in IgA myeloma.

  • Russell bodies: Hyaline intracytoplasmic inclusions containing Ig.
  • Mott cells/morula cells: Plasma cells containing multiple grape-like cytoplasmic inclusions comprised of Ig
  • Flame cells: Vermillion-staining, glycogen-rich IgA in cytoplasmic projections
  • Thesaurocytes: Dilated endoplasmic reticulum cisternae

Image – A binucleate plasma cell with intranuclear Dutcher cells.

questions.text: Wernicke-Korsakoff psychosis is seen due to the deficiency of ______.
questions.solution:
Wernicke-Korsakoff psychosis is seen due to the deficiency of thiamine. Thiamine is a cofactor for several important enzymes and is also involved in the conduction of the axon potential and synaptic transmission.

Wernicke's encephalopathy/alcoholic encephalopathy is an acute neurological disorder.

The triad of symptoms seen is (GOA):

  • Global Confusion
  • Ophthalmoplegia ( first symptom to improve with thiamine +dextrose infusion)
  • Ataxia

Treatment

It is a medical emergency and requires immediate administration of thiamine 100 mg IV or IM for 3 days followed by two to three times a day orally for 1 to 2 weeks.

Glucose infusions may precipitate Wernicke’s disease in a previously unaffected patient or cause a rapid worsening of an early form of the disease. For this reason, thiamine should be administered to all alcoholic patients requiring parenteral glucose.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in marasmus and not in kwashiorkor?
questions.solution:
• Children with marasmus have a voracious appetite, whereas children with kwashiorkor often refuse to eat.
  • Hypoalbuminemia is seen in kwashiorkor, which leads to edema.

Related Pearl: Differences between Marasmus and Kwashiorkar

Marasmus Kwashiorkor
Seen in infants less than 1 year of age Seen in older children (6 months to 3 years of age)
Total calorie deficit Protein deficit
NO edema Edema is prominent
Voracious appetite, no apathy Apathy and loss of appetite
Severe muscle wasting Muscle wasting mild or absent
Prominent ribs Protuberant abdomen
No Fatty liver, no subcutaneous fat Fatty liver, Subcutaneous fat preserved

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient who presented with a scrotal swelling underwent an orchidectomy. The image below shows the histopathology findings. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Based on the gross and microscopic appearance of the specimen, the diagnosis is seminoma.

The gross specimen shows a well-circumscribed, pale, gray-white, fleshy, homogenous mass, with a lobulated cut surface, usually devoid of hemorrhage or necrosis. Histopathology shows uniform tumor cells with abundant clear cytoplasm, distinct cell borders, and large central nuclei. There is a sparse lymphocytic infiltrate. Classically, they have a fried egg appearance.

Option B: Yolk-sac tumor has a yellowish-white, mucinous appearance.

Option C: Embryonal cell carcinoma appears variegated with foci of hemorrhage or necrosis.

Option D: Teratomas also have a variegated appearance but have cysts reflecting the multiplicity of tissue types.

questions.text: What is the single most important galactopoetic hormone in post-natal women?
questions.solution:
Prolactin is the single most important galactopoietic hormone in postnatal women.

Function Definition Hormone
Mammogenesis Breast growth and development

Estrogen (ductal growth)

Progesterone (alveolar growth)
Lactogenesis Initiation of milk secretion Prolactin
Galactokinesis Ejection of milk Oxytocin
Galactopoiesis Maintainence of lactation Prolactin

questions.text: A child on beta 2 agonists for the treatment of bronchial asthma may exhibit all of the following except:
questions.solution:
β2 agonists are associated with hyperglycemia probably due to β2 receptor-mediated glycogenolysis and glucagon release.

Adverse effects of beta 2 agonists are

  • Muscle tremors: Direct effect on beta 2 receptors in skeletal muscles and due to hypokalemia
  • Tachycardia: Direct effect on cardiac beta 2 receptors, indirect sympathetic stimulation due to vasodilator action on beta 2 receptors
  • Hypokalemia: Direct effect on skeletal muscle uptake of K+ ions
  • Hypoxemia
  • Hyperglycaemia
  • Hyperlipidemia
  • Tolerance: Desensitization on long-term use

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman has a resting heart rate of 70-beats/min. The pressure-volume diagram of her left ventricle is given below. What is her cardiac output (in mL/min)? (Point 2 corresponds to 120 ml)
questions.solution:
In this case, the patient has a heart rate of 70-beats/min and the stroke volume can be determined from the given pressure-volume diagram.

Point 2 corresponds to the EDV(End diastolic volume) = 120 mL
Point 1 corresponds to the ESV(End systolic volume) = 50 mL

Thus, stroke volume (SV) = EDV – ESV = 120 – 50 = 70 mL

Therefore, Cardiac output = HR X SV = 70 X 70 = 4900 mL/min.

questions.text: Best investigation for pulmonary embolism _____
questions.solution:
Pulmonary CT angiography /MDCT is the best investigation for pulmonary embolism. The dye is injected through the intravenous route.

The below figure is a CT angiography demonstrating multiple filling defects both at the bifurcation (saddle pulmonary embolism) and in the pulmonary arteries.

  • V/Q scan is done in pregnant females.
  • Investigation of choice for an aortic aneurysm is CT angiography.

questions.text: The external validity of a screening test is related to?
questions.solution:
External validity of a screening test is related to generalizability.

Validity (accuracy) refers to what extent the test accurately measures which it sets out to measure. It refers to the closeness with which measured values agree with "true" values. 

While assessing the validity of a research study, two kinds of validity are involved:

  • External validity: If the study sample is truly representative of the population from which it was drawn, then the study is said to have external validity. Its findings can be applied to the entire population as well and therefore it is said to be generalizable.
  • Internal validity: Here the results of the study are valid for the sample of patients who were actually studied.

Note: Precision (reliability or reproducibility) is a measure of the repeatability of a test. That is, the test must give consistent results when repeated more than once on the same individual or material, under the same conditions.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man chronic smoker presented with flecks of blood in his sputum. He is currently on treatment for COPD and hypertension. His BMI is 31 kg/m² and he has central obesity. His RBS is 261 mg/dl. During further evaluation, he is found to have high ACTH levels that remained high even after administration of high-dose dexamethasone. What is the underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Elevated ACTH levels that do not get suppressed by a high-dose dexamethasone test are suggestive of Cushing’s syndrome secondary to an ectopic ACTH-secreting tumor. Considering the patient's smoking history and presentation with hemoptysis, it is likely to be a lung tumor.

Dynamic testing for Cushing’s syndrome
  High dose dexamethasone suppression test CRH stimulation test
Pituitary adenoma Positive (suppressed cortisol) Positive (increase in ACTH and cortisol)
Ectopic ACTH Negative Negative
Iatrogenic: Suppressed ACTH levels that are not affected by dynamic testing
Adrenal mass or hyperplasia:  Suppressed ACTH levels that are not affected by dynamic testing

Ectopic sources of ACTH include small cell lung cancers and pulmonary carcinoid tumors. The most effective treatment strategy is the management of the underlying SCLC or carcinoid. 

Option A: Exogenous steroid administration presents with suppressed ACTH levels.

Option B: Pituitary adenoma presents with elevated ACTH but a high-dose dexamethasone suppression test is positive (suppressed).

Option C: Adrenal adenoma presents with suppressed ACTH levels.

questions.text: Symptoms of sinusitis includes all except
questions.solution:
Diplopia is not seen in sinusitis.

Related Pearl: Symptoms of Sinusitis

Symptoms of maxillary sinusitis:

  • Pain over the upper jaw, aggravated by stooping, coughing & chewing
  • Constitutional symptoms like malaise and fever
  • Headache in the frontal region
  • Nasal and postnasal discharge
  • Redness and edema of cheeks
  • Tenderness on pressing over the anterior wall of the antrum

Symptoms of frontal sinusitis:

  • Frontal headache/ office headache with characteristic periodicity i.e. starts early morning and gradually increases and reaches its peak by about mid-day and then starts subsiding
  • Tenderness on pressing on the floor of the frontal sinus, just above the medial canthus
  • Nasal discharge
  • Edema of the upper eyelid

Symptoms of ethmoid sinusitis:

  • Pain over the bridge of the nose and deep to the eye that is aggravated by the movements of the eyeball
  • Edema of both eyelids,
  • Nasal discharge

Symptoms of sphenoid sinusitis:

  • Headache localized to occiput or vertex
  • Postnasal discharge

questions.text: An 8 month-old baby is brought to the pediatric clinic with symptoms of diarrhea, hair loss and failure to thrive. On clinical examination, there is inflammation of the skin around the mouth and the perianal region. The mineral deficiency responsible for this disease is?
questions.solution:
The symptoms and clinical findings, strongly suggest a diagnosis of Acrodermatitis enteropathica which is due to the deficiency of zinc.

It is an autosomal recessive disease due to a defect in zinc absorbing transmembrane protein.

Symptoms:

  • Growth retardation
  • Diarrhea
  • Alopecia
  • Rash involving the extremities, face, and perineum(rash is characterized by vesicular and pustular crusting with scaling and erythema)
  • Gonadal atrophy
  • Muscle wasting
  • Impaired wound healing
